newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: ING ON LOOKOUT TO BUY INSURERS IN U.S..
newsitem.headline: ING ON LOOKOUT TO BUY INSURERS IN U.S..

text.p: Dutch financial services group ING NV said on Wednesday its priority would be to acquire an insurer in the United States rather than a bank.

"The insurance market has our priority at the moment," said ING board member Cees Maas during a press conference in which he unveiled more details on ING's intended bourse listing in New York in June.

"We are actively looking around (for takeovers) as we want to play a strong role in the American insurance market," Maas said. He saw strong growth ahead in the market for pension and life insurance products.
ING said the intended listing in the U.S. would enable the group to finance mergers and acquisitions in the United States with shares.
"The payment of an acquisition with your own shares is usually more attractive due to tax-advantages," Maas said.
ING said it was currently not in talks with any party in the U.S. on a possible takeover. "But things can change quickly," he added.
ING said it wanted to expand its shareholder base through the listing in the U.S., as about 13 percent of all its shares were owned by U.S. and Canadian investors.
A total of 52 percent of all ING shares are owned by Dutch investors, mainly institutions, but a substantional amount is in the hands of private investors.
ING said in a statement it wanted to increase its visibility in the U.S.
"The U.S. is the largest capital market in the world and the listing facilitates ING Group's future access to this market," ING said.
